Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 09:25PM bre wrote: Hi English,  I had a right mastectomy with 12 nodes removed 6 yr ago.  Like they say, it's just skin and fat so there is very little pain.  Definitely the node removal was the worse part.  I agree with putting things you use frequently within easy reach for a little while. It will be a little uncomfortable to reach high.  I didn't need anything for pain except for tylenol.  The button down shirts with a pocket for drains is a great idea.  Remember to empty the drain every 8 hr at least so it doesn't clot off.  If it does then you have to milk it to get it working again.  After emptying mine, I folded it in half and then half again, put the stopper in, and let it go and it drained really well.  I didn't need any help with bathing after someone helped me wash the soaps and blood off my back after the surgery.  Didn't need any help with dressing.  I was driving in a week with a little discomfort and back to work in 2 weeks.  The small travel pillow worked really well for me and I still use it at night since there's no breast there to prop my arm on.  Silk jammies helped me to slide and move around easily.  I didn't have recon either.  Stairs should be no problem for you.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Advice on post surgical (mx) care EnglishMajor bre

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 07:01PM bre wrote: I lived about 10-15 min away from the onc.  I took ativan before chemo and the chemo appt with onc visit lasted only about 2 hours.  The ativan made driving a little tricky.  My hubby went to the first appt so we could see how I would react.  After that I drove myself and had someone on call.  Oh, I had aloxi before the adriamycin and cytoxan.  Napped well listening to my ipod and then napped again at home.  Drink lots to flush the stuff out of your system.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Can you drive yourself to chemo appointments? arnie SoCalLisa

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2008 11:14PM bre wrote: Hi Simvog, I am about the same size as you.  I had  a right mast.  I did the same as you....felt that I just couldn't go to a fitter and put it off for months.  After I went, I couldn't figure out why I waited so long.  The bras and prosthetic she fitted me for were sooo much more comfortable and natural feeling.  Once you get fitted and know about what you want, you can also get bras, forms, etc from tlc catalogue put out by the american cancer society.  They have an online site and you can also get catalogues delivered to your home.  They are much cheaper but you need to know what you want and size so you don't waste time and money.  Good luck! Bre 1.7cm tumor plus malignant microcalcifications, er+/pr-/her2+++, stage 1, nuclear grade 8, no nodes, idc
Posts.Title: Need help after one sided mastectomy havehope marvinr

Posts.Content: bre wrote: Hi,  I got the problem with my affected arm diagnosed as atrophic dermatitis.  I got a prescription cortisone cream for it which healed it nicely.  Right at the end of the dermatitis, my finger became sore and was slightly reddened.  I thought perhaps I picked up the flat iron too close to the heat and gave myself a slight burn vs bacteria entering the broken skin from the dermatitis while working at the hospital.  That was Monday when I noticed it.  Today I kept it covered at work.  Tonight after church I took off the bandaid.  My finger is definitely swollen, thumping with every heartbeat, and the sore area has a white center.  I can probably have someone look at it tomorrow at work but can anyone think of something that I could do tonight?  I put bactroban antibiotic ointment on it this morning.  I don't want it to soak it and don't think using a heating pad would be a good idea either.  It seems to be getting visibly worse as the evening goes on and hate risking lymphedema buy waiting til morning.  Any ideas anyone?  Thanks for your help! Dx 1/16/2004, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/12 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Hello apple bre

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 11:01PM bre wrote: Onc told me that when I missed a cycle then my hair would figure out that I wasn't trying to kill it and it would start to grow back.  My hairdresser told me that it would grow at the rate of 1/2 inch a month.  My hair came back in full but very soft and fine.  It is the same color as before chemo.  I just wish someone would have given me the idea of spiking my hair while it was short.  Once I started doing that, everyone thought the short hair was planned and very natural.  last chemo was April 20.  Went without wig the end of July but people would comment that I had been on chemo.  Went without wig again then in September and spiked the hair and people loved it even though I was uncomfortable with how short it was.  First haircut to even ends was Thanksgiving.  hated having no hair and love having my hair back.  Seems like it takes forever but it will come!

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2009 01:24AM bre wrote: Hi bad,  am on arimidex and zometa.  Got both seasonal and H1N1 vaccine shots (not live virus) and felt no effects from either one.  Baby grandson and son both have the flu and have been pretty sick.  Wouldn't get the mist since it's a live virus and gives you a mild case of the flu to build your immunity.
Posts.Title: H1N1 Poll--ALL STAGES WELCOME! badboob67 wildgardener

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 12:32AM - edited Mar 13, 2009 12:34AM by bre Hi Shadow,  My story is similar to yours.  Postponed my mammo for a few months because I thought I was too busy.  Beat myself up pretty bad for that which was counter productive.  Had no history of breast cancer in my family and never expected to.  I was diagnosed at 49.  Couldn't eat, sleep, etc while going through the diagnosis process.  Called to mammo center on Fri and ultrasound done, core biopsy on Tues., results in of breast cancer on Wed, saw breast surgeon same day after telling office people I couldn't eat, sleep, etc.  Mastectomy scheduled for Monday with skin sparing technique.  Didn't go for immediate recon because that would have delayed things for who knows how long to coordinate things.  Didn't have a choice about mastectomy because between the tumor and malignant microcalcifications, 3/4 of the breast was involved.  Pathology report after the mastectomy was a little different in the tumor size was smaller and it was not inflammatory bc like the biopsy suggested but was invasive ductal.  If you go for lumpectomy, ask if there will be a pathologist doing a frozen section at the surgery.  Then he can check immediately for clear margins while you are still asleep and they can get it all and no repeat surgeries. At first I felt like you and very upset.  Sure I would never see my sons marry, etc.  Five years later, I am doing great even though mine was a very aggressive cancer.  No signs of recurrence and working full time and doing whatever I want.  So what you are going through is no fun but it is doable.  Take deep breaths, keep as positive as you can, try to stay productively busy, and avoid negative people that will just absorb energy you don't have.  There are alot of great ladies here that will help you through all this.  Good luck with your appointment today.  Let us know what happens.
